questions.question_text: Which two reasons would cause an LSP to break between two PE routers? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
cause LSP break !!! i think if mpls is not enabled there's no LSP in first place

Selected Answer: AE
A. Lost LDP adjacency: The Label Distribution Protocol (LDP) is used to distribute labels in MPLS networks. If the LDP adjacency between two PE routers is lost, the routers will not be able to exchange labels, causing the LSP (Label Switched Path) to break.

E. MPLS not enabled: If MPLS is not enabled on either of the PE routers, the LSP cannot be established, as MPLS relies on the ability to swap labels across routers to forward packets along a path.

comments.content:
The other options:

B. Matching labels: While matching labels are important for LSPs to work properly, mismatched labels (not matching) could cause issues, but matching labels themselves aren't the cause of a broken LSP.

C. Prefix mismatch: A prefix mismatch would typically affect routing, but not directly cause an LSP to break unless it impacts the label distribution or forwarding.

D. IGP hello adjacency: This refers to the hello protocol for IGP (Interior Gateway Protocol) neighbors like OSPF or EIGRP. It's crucial for routing, but it doesn't directly affect the LSP in MPLS unless it impacts the overall routing table, which would indirectly affect MPLS label distribution.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
Prefix mismatch would more likely cause routing issues, but it is not directly related to the LSP breaking, as LSPs are built using label information rather than IP prefix information directly.

Selected Answer: AC
A & C are correct

The label bindings must correspond to the prefixes and subnet masks in the routing tables. 
If there's a mismatch, the labels will not be used properly, causing the LSP to fail.


i think E is incorrect, if MPLS is not enabled on the routers, there won’t be any LSPs to break.


https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/multiprotocol-label-switching-mpls/mpls/23565-troubleshoot-mpls-vpn.html#cause:~:text=If%20label%20bindings,devices%20will%20fail.

comments.content:
Correct and taken from the link you provided:
If label bindings are received from a downstream neighbor for prefixes (including subnet mask) which do not appear in a router's routing and CEF tables, these bindings will not be used. In a similar manner, if a router advertises labels for a subnet/subnet mask pair, which do not correspond to the routing updates also advertised by this router for the same subnet/subnet mask pair, these labels will not be used by upstream neighbors and the Label Switched Path (LSP) between these devices will fail.

discussion.content:
AC 

A: Like many other protocols, LDP first establishes a (neighbor adjacency) before it exchanges label information. and each router has unique LSR. 

C: When we use LDP on Cisco IOS, we locally generate a label for each prefix that we can find in the RIB, except for BGP prefixes. This information is then added to the LIB (Label Information Base). 
The information in the LIB is used to build the LFIB (Label Forwarding Information Base). When the router has to forward a packet with a MPLS label on it, it will use the LFIB for forwarding decisions.

I don't think E is accurate as if MPLS not enabled the Adjacency between the PEs will not form the start, my hint the question asking about already formed session and got broken.

Selected Answer: AE
I thought A and E. Anyway, it do not think LSP break with prefix mismatch, so personally C is wrong. A & E seem best here
Im not sure on A because of the word "adjacency". I mean LDP issues yes, would cause the break between PE routers but adjacency?

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/multiprotocol-label-switching-mpls/mpls/23565-troubleshoot-mpls-vpn.html#cause
I think its CE

questions.question_text:
SIMULATION
-

//IMG//



Guidelines
-

This is a lab item in which tasks will be performed on virtual devices.

• Refer to the Tasks tab to view the tasks for this lab item.
• Refer to the Topology tab to access the device console(s) and perform the tasks.
• Console access is available for all required devices by clicking the device icon or using the tab(s) above the console window.
• All necessary preconfigurations have been applied.
• Do not change the enable password or hostname for any device.
• Save your configurations to NVRAM before moving to the next item.
• Click Next at the bottom of the screen to submit this lab and move to the next question.
• When Next is clicked, the lab closes and cannot be reopened.


Topology
-

//IMG//



Tasks
-

Troubleshoot and resolve the issues to achieve these goals:

1. Ensure that R1 reaches the prefix 10.6.66.6 without any single point of failure in the path. Do not use a static route or policy-based routing to accomplish this.
2. Ensure that R1 loopback 1 reaches to R6’s loopback 1 by following the path through R1, R3, R5 to R6 and vice versa. Use metric values K1 = 100000, K2=1, K3=255, K4=10, K5=1500 to modify the default metric in EIGRP if required. Do not use a route-map.
3. Ensure that on R3, prefix 10.0.56.6/32 uses the SP1 to route to the Internet, whereas prefix 172.16.12.2/32 uses the SP2 to route to the Internet. Do not use BGP to accomplish this. Use the pre-configured route-maps SP1 and SP2 and modify to accomplish the task if required. Use the ping and trace commands from R6 and R2 to prefixes 209.165.202.132 and 209.165.202.128, respectively to verify the results.

Correct me if I am wrong, the submitted answer is almost correct. The answer is missing the ACLs needed in place on the route map. These ACLs tell traffic from 10.0.56.6/32 and 172.16.12.2 to use the correct service providers. Without the ACLs in place all ingress traffic will go out to either SP1 or SP2. Check running configuration for preconfigured commands such as ACLs or distance. Remove them and set proper configurations.

I had this question on exam. same topology but different question. I am so confused.

1. verify that R2 can reach the prefix 10.5.55.5 without a single point of failure in the path. Do not use static routes or route maps for this

2. follow the path in the order of R1, R5, R6, or vice versa, and verify that R1 loopback 0 reaches R6 loopback 0.

If necessary, change the default EIGRP metric using metric values K1 = 100000, K2 = 1, K3 = 255, K4 = 10, and K5 = 1500.
Do not use route maps.

3. in R3, ensure that the prefix 10.0.0.0/8 routes to the Internet using SP1 and the prefix 172.16.0.0/12 routes to the Internet using SP2.
Do not use BGP for this. Use the preconfigured route maps SP1 and SP2 and modify them to perform the task as needed; use ping and trace commands from R5 and R1 to verify results.
any thoughts on how we accomplish task-3 this without BGP ?

comments.content:
according to the question you can't use BGP so i used PBR on R3 interfaces after i redistributed BGP on both OSPF and EIGRP.
 Please share your thoughts on the below,

R3(config-router)#do sh run | sec ospf| eigrp
router eigrp 10
 network 0.0.0.0
 redistribute ospf 1 metric 100000 1 255 10 1500
 redistribute bgp 5500 metric 100000 1 255 10 1500
 distance 120 10.0.35.5 0.0.0.0
 eigrp router-id 33.33.33.33
router ospf 1
 router-id 3.3.3.3
 priority 10
 redistribute eigrp 10 subnets
 redistribute bgp 5500 subnets
 network 192.168.0.0 0.0.255.255 area 0
 network 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255 area 0

================

R3(config)#int e0/1
R3(config-if)#ip policy route-map SP1

R3(config-if)#int e0/0
R3(config-if)#ip policy route-map SP2
did this config get you a loop when pinging from R1 to R6 loopback, I cant re-create the loop

Task-3

R3#sh run | sec acc|route-m
route-map SP-1 permit 10
 match ip address 10
 set ip next-hop 209.165.201.2
route-map SP-1 permit 20
route-map IPS-2 permit 10
 match ip address 11
 set ip next-hop 209.165.200.226
route-map IPS-2 permit 20
access-list 10 permit 10.0.56.6
access-list 11 permit 172.16.12.2
R3#

after configuring the task 3 as per your configuration, if i ping from R6 to R1...packets will go to internet.it wont go to R1. but in routing table in R6 route will show from R6-R5-R3-R1. Am i correct?

Its best practice to put specific source ip address when you are changing the default distance, hence

# distance 120 10.0.35.5 0.0.0.0
10.0.35.5 === R5 ip address on eth0/0

R3-HQ(config-router)#do sh run | sec eig
router eigrp 10
 network 0.0.0.0

R4#sh run | sec eig

discussion.content:
I replicate the SIM with the exact subnets, this is task 1-2

R3#sh run | sec rou
no ip source-route
router eigrp 10
 network 0.0.0.0
 redistribute ospf 1 metric 100000 1 255 10 1500
 distance 120 10.0.35.5 0.0.0.0
 eigrp router-id 33.33.33.33
router ospf 1
 router-id 3.3.3.3
 priority 10
 redistribute eigrp 10 subnets
 network 192.168.0.0 0.0.255.255 area 0
 network 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255 area 0
=================

R4#sh run | sec rou
router eigrp 10
 network 0.0.0.0
 redistribute ospf 1 metric 100000 1 255 10 1500
 eigrp router-id 44.44.44.44
router ospf 1
 router-id 4.4.4.4
 redistribute eigrp 10 subnets
 network 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255 area 0
R4#

I have had a few variants of this lab on my tests. They have changed some metrics but overall the test is more or less the same.
But please be aware that the access lists referenced by SP1 and SP2 sometimes (always?) contain block statements. So you have to recreate those with the correct permit statements.

One time I needed to change the AD of RIP on R4 as well, instead of changing the metric.

I figured it out. R4 mutually redistributes EIGRP and OSPF into eachother before R3 does redistribution. After R3 does redistribution R3 has 2 paths to 10.6.66.6 network. R3 chooses EIGRP as it has lower administrative distance. However in the simlet we use distance command to make EIGRP distance higher, than external OSPF distance of 110. In my lab this is what it looks like, for EIGRP 1 and OSPF 1 process (I did not use process number of 10): router eigrp 1
 network 10.0.35.3 0.0.0.0
 network 10.3.3.0 0.0.0.255
 network 10.3.33.0 0.0.0.255
 redistribute bgp 1 metric 1 1 1 1 1
 distance 125 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255 66

comments.content:
R4 mutually redistributes before R3 does: router eigrp 1
 network 10.0.46.4 0.0.0.0
 network 10.4.4.0 0.0.0.255
 network 10.4.44.0 0.0.0.255
 redistribute ospf 1 metric 1 1 1 1 1
 redistribute rip metric 1000000 1 255 10 1500
 distance 125 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255 66
 eigrp router-id 4.4.4.4
Now because R3 has distance 125 command to 10.6.66.6, we see R3 chooses the path to R4, on the other side of the network. 

R3#show ip route

<...........>
D 10.5.5.0/24 [90/409600] via 10.0.35.5, 00:22:17, Ethernet0/1
D 10.5.55.0/24 [90/409600] via 10.0.35.5, 00:22:17, Ethernet0/1
O E2 10.6.6.0/24 [110/20] via 172.16.13.1, 00:05:05, Ethernet0/0
O E2 10.6.66.0/24 [110/20] via 172.16.13.1, 00:05:05, Ethernet0/0


Notice that for the 10.5.55.0/24 loopback of R5, R3 still chooses EIGRP 1 as it has lower AD, but since 10.6.66.0/24 has distance of 125 for EIGRP, R3 chooses the path to R4

The above traceroute goes through R4 which is longer path. The question asks for R1 -->R3 --> R5 --> R6.
When we issue this command on R3: 
R3(config)#
R3(config-router)#no distance 125 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255 66
Now R3 has 10.6.66.6 as a better route in eigrp compared to OSPF E2 route of R4, and redistributes it into OSPF 1 and installs it into LSDB.
Now R3 has better route:
R3#show ip ro
*Jul 16 22:22:07.702: %SYS-5-CONFIG_I: Configured from console by console
R3#show ip route
<.......>
D 10.5.5.0/24 [90/409600] via 10.0.35.5, 00:02:15, Ethernet0/1
D 10.5.55.0/24 [90/409600] via 10.0.35.5, 00:02:15, Ethernet0/1
D 10.6.6.0/24 [90/51379200] via 10.0.35.5, 00:02:15, Ethernet0/1
D 10.6.66.0/24 [90/51379200] via 10.0.35.5, 00:02:15, Ethernet0/1
And now R3 installs this into its OSPF LSDB and advertises it to R1.

Now R1 has the route advertised from R3. And the traceroute:
R1#trace 10.6.66.6
Type escape sequence to abort.
Tracing the route to 10.6.66.6
VRF info: (vrf in name/id, vrf out name/id)
 1 172.16.13.3 20 msec 6 msec 5 msec
 2 10.0.35.5 1 msec 6 msec 6 msec
 3 10.0.56.6 6 msec 5 msec 5 msec

here is my config if you want to practice: R3:
router eigrp 1
 network 10.0.35.3 0.0.0.0
 network 10.3.3.0 0.0.0.255
 network 10.3.33.0 0.0.0.255
 redistribute bgp 1 metric 1 1 1 1 1
 eigrp router-id 3.3.3.3
!
router ospf 1
 router-id 3.3.3.3
 redistribute eigrp 1 subnets
 redistribute bgp 1 subnets
 network 10.3.3.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
 network 10.3.33.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
 network 172.16.13.3 0.0.0.0 area 0
 default-information originate
!
router bgp 1
 bgp log-neighbor-changes
 redistribute eigrp 1
 redistribute ospf 1
 neighbor 209.165.200.226 remote-as 2
 neighbor 209.165.201.1 remote-as 2
(the bgp is for the SP neighbors)

here is my config for R4 if you want to practice: router eigrp 1
 network 10.0.46.4 0.0.0.0
 network 10.4.4.0 0.0.0.255
 network 10.4.44.0 0.0.0.255
 redistribute ospf 1 metric 1 1 1 1 1
 redistribute rip metric 1000000 1 255 10 1500
 distance 125 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255 66
 eigrp router-id 4.4.4.4
!
router ospf 1
 router-id 4.4.4.4
 redistribute eigrp 1 subnets
 network 10.4.4.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
 network 10.4.44.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
 network 172.16.24.4 0.0.0.0 area 0
!
router rip
 version 2
 redistribute ospf 1 metric 4
 redistribute eigrp 1 metric 4
 network 10.0.0.0
 no auto-summary

Note in my lab I didn't have to modify the eigrp redistribution metric, I set it to redistribute ospf 1 metric 1 1 1 1 1. You can do it how the exam asks for, I recommend it. Sometimes we modify the redistribution metric to pool traffic to one side of the network.

The same is true for R1 as now R1 has best path through R4, as R3 never advertises the 10.6.66.6 route into OSPF from EIGRP distance 125, as it already has a route to 10.6.66.6 distance 110.
R1#trace 10.6.66.6 source L0
Type escape sequence to abort.
Tracing the route to 10.6.66.6
VRF info: (vrf in name/id, vrf out name/id)
 1 172.16.12.2 6 msec 1 msec 5 msec
 2 172.16.24.4 6 msec 5 msec 5 msec
 3 10.0.46.6 6 msec 5 msec 5 msec

discussion.content: I cannot get the loop to work properly, as it did on the exam. When I pinged 10.66.6.6 from R1 source Loopback0/1 it goes to R6 without a loop. I am mutually redistributing on both R3 and R4, but this causes suboptimal routing, and not a routing loop ~ any suggestions?

discussion.content: I got this SIM in my Exam, please pay attention to the ACL in my test the ACLs were already created and matched in the route map. The ACLs have a Deny for the networks 172.0.0.0 and 10.0.0.0. So you need to delete it before starting the configuration.

Had this lab on the exam, pretty much the same - and the provided answer in config is pretty accurate.
I had a different metric set under eigrp distance for 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255, but removing it fixed the issue so not too important
Used traceroute to troubleshoot flow as suggested
Is that provided answer is correct?

Be aware, because they can have different metrics on the routers on the real sim. Ensure that R6 takes the route through R5 instead of R4 (because the PBR won’t work that way). If it does, you can configure the link between R6 and R4 with lower bandwith OR the link between R6 and R5 with higher.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which configuration resolves the issue?

comments.content: I agree
Agreed.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Seems:"Rollover in progress, 1 neighbor(2) using old key(s): key id 1 algorithm MD5"
Indicated neighbor uses MD5 authentication.

To fix please set MD5 authentication configuration back:

CSR103(config)#interface fastEthernet 0/0
CSR103(config-if)#ip ospf message-digest-key 1 md5 cisco
CSR103(config-if)#ip ospf authentication message-digest

Above will automatically "remove" wrongly configured "ip ospf authentication key-chain ospf"

C is currently configured on the router, but with a different hma-sha-256:
show ip ospf interface e0/0
 Cryptographic authentication enabled
 Sending SA: Key 1, Algorithm HMAC-SHA-1 - key chain ospf

Selected Answer: B
B is corerct
